content.html: Browsers have this to some extent. It is called CSP there: developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web…
content.text: Browsers have this to some extent. It is called CSP there: developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web…

content.html: I've only ever used CSP features to protect sites I maintain, is there a way to really leverage that in user land? The idea being I want client side JS to still work without it being able to open websockets, use fetch(), etc. Is that some CSP magic I haven't found yet? 👀
content.text:
I've only ever used CSP features to protect sites I maintain, is there a way to really leverage that in user land?

The idea being I want client side JS to still work without it being able to open websockets, use fetch(), etc. Is that some CSP magic I haven't found yet?  👀

content.html:
Code splitting seems to be a real challenge regardless of framework

Utility classes used on any page often bleed out to every page on the site

Call it a bundler challenge or even an optimization for page transitions, but I don’t want complex /admin styles on my landing page
content.text: Code splitting seems to be a real challenge regardless of frameworkUtility classes used on any page often bleed out to every page on the siteCall it a bundler challenge or even an optimization for page transitions, but I don’t want complex /admin styles on my landing page

content.html:
Logical properties like padding-inline or block-size fundamentally won’t work

i.e. it only really works with left-to-right (LTR) languages

That’s fine for a smaller project, but a show stopper for something a properly translated site like @astro docs
content.text: Logical properties like padding-inline or block-size fundamentally won’t worki.e. it only really works with left-to-right (LTR) languagesThat’s fine for a smaller project, but a show stopper for something a properly translated site like @astro docs

content.html: This is what in my mind when I first read the tweet 😂 en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Router_(c…
content.text:
This is what in my mind when I first read the tweet 😂
en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Router_(c…

🌶️ If you can’t describe how a router works in two sentences or less, it’s too complex

A developer that isn’t familiar with the code should be able to go from a URL to all code require to actually render the page.

tonysull.co/articles/routi…

content.html: This has been a #TonyTake 🌶️
content.text: This has been a #TonyTake 🌶️

content.html: I'd say the router is one of those design patterns that isnlike the jumper that was just an inch too bit on everybody that tired it
content.text: I'd say the router is one of those design patterns that isnlike the jumper that was just an inch too bit on everybody that tired it

content.html:
The sheer complexity of all the different routing solutions today should raise serious red flags

What we really need is a spec that works well enough for every framework. Sure it will be limiting, but I'd take limiting over /(admin)/blog/[slug]/edit/$page-layout.html any day
content.text: The sheer complexity of all the different routing solutions today should raise serious red flagsWhat we really need is a spec that works well enough for every framework. Sure it will be limiting, but I'd take limiting over /(admin)/blog/[slug]/edit/$page-layout.html any day

content.html:
Been sitting on this rant for a while now, time to call it good enough to actually publish it

Routing is effectively table stakes for a modern framework at this point

We really need to start fresh with what server routing should really look like in a JavaScript framework
content.text: Been sitting on this rant for a while now, time to call it good enough to actually publish itRouting is effectively table stakes for a modern framework at this pointWe really need to start fresh with what server routing should really look like in a JavaScript framework

content.html: It'd be amazing to see a push for shared specs at the framework level, we all keep chasing the same problems. I finally published my "we need one router" rant this weekend, so much effort is spent reinventing the wheel! tonysull.co/articles/routi…
content.text:
It'd be amazing to see a push for shared specs at the framework level, we all keep chasing the same problems.

I finally published my "we need one router" rant this weekend, so much effort is spent reinventing the wheel!

tonysull.co/articles/routi…

content.html: It's definitely not a new idea, but worth dusting off now that we aren't trying to render the entire world in a SPA Server-rendered HTML partials + using the DOM as an Object Model instead of a JS app serialization format sure is compelling
content.text:
It's definitely not a new idea, but worth dusting off now that we aren't trying to render the entire world in a SPA

Server-rendered HTML partials + using the DOM as an Object Model instead of a JS app serialization format sure is compelling

content.html: I like your thinking: matthewphillips.info/programming/po…
content.text: I like your thinking: matthewphillips.info/programming/po…

The idea of a JS framework based on Finite State Machines got me thinking

Its really interesting to see JS frameworks shift back towards server rendering.

What if we leaning into web components and treating the DOM as our state?

tonysull.co/notes/dom-as-s…

content.html: Combine that with streaming and loading what you need on demand.
content.text: Combine that with streaming and loading what you need on demand.

content.html: Well who doesn't like drifting...
content.text: Well who doesn't like drifting...

content.html:
At best you’ll find these issues after the fact, and in all likelihood you may never even notice them

Server-side rendering is important because you own the entire infrastructure up to the point of sending the actual HTML back to the user’s device

You can distribute your APIs, add caching layers, and distribute your database if that’s needed

With CSR you’re way more limited

2/2
content.text: At best you’ll find these issues after the fact, and in all likelihood you may never even notice themServer-side rendering is important because you own the entire infrastructure up to the point of sending the actual HTML back to the user’s deviceYou can distribute your APIs, add caching layers, and distribute your database if that’s neededWith CSR you’re way more limited2/2

content.html:
They define your team structure and hiring goals

The lines between backend and frontend blur, to the point that there may not be a distinction anymore

Infrastructure, maintainability, testability, and scaling all change

????
content.text: They define your team structure and hiring goalsThe lines between backend and frontend blur, to the point that there may not be a distinction anymoreInfrastructure, maintainability, testability, and scaling all change????

content.html:
If you have, or plan to have, a public API it may need to be entirely separate from your own frontend project

Now that RPCs are new stew rather than 3 day old halibut (RIP Anthony Bourdain), your project is using APIs created by the bundler without versioning or documentation

????
content.text: If you have, or plan to have, a public API it may need to be entirely separate from your own frontend projectNow that RPCs are new stew rather than 3 day old halibut (RIP Anthony Bourdain), your project is using APIs created by the bundler without versioning or documentation????

content.html:
Almost every technical hire you make will likely need to be a full-stack engineer, bonus if they specialize a bit

Your SQL specialist will need to understand bundlers, JS tooling, and may need to know what "import server", "use server", and "use client" all do

Your HTML/CSS and accessibility experts will need to know how to work in your JS component framework of choice

If you pull in Tailwind because styling in JS can be painful, they'll need to know that as well

????
content.text: Almost every technical hire you make will likely need to be a full-stack engineer, bonus if they specialize a bitYour SQL specialist will need to understand bundlers, JS tooling, and may need to know what "import server", "use server", and "use client" all doYour HTML/CSS and accessibility experts will need to know how to work in your JS component framework of choiceIf you pull in Tailwind because styling in JS can be painful, they'll need to know that as well????

content.html:
Bug reproducability is going to be tricky too

Application flow now moves between SSR, client rendering, and functions marshaled back to the server via RPC calls

When a user hits an error, where do you look? How do you recreate it locally? And how do you automate a test?

????
content.text: Bug reproducability is going to be tricky tooApplication flow now moves between SSR, client rendering, and functions marshaled back to the server via RPC callsWhen a user hits an error, where do you look? How do you recreate it locally? And how do you automate a test?????

content.html:
I'll assume that you're deploying to serverless or edge

In that case, you likely can't recreate the production environment if you wanted to

Devs won't be able to locally reproduce the deployed hardware, OS, or network. Same for the end user's hardware and network conditions

????
content.text: I'll assume that you're deploying to serverless or edgeIn that case, you likely can't recreate the production environment if you wanted toDevs won't be able to locally reproduce the deployed hardware, OS, or network. Same for the end user's hardware and network conditions????

children.name: Web 3.0 正式来临，而它并不是区块链。

content.html:
Web 3.0 正式来临，而它并不是区块链

当我们谈到 Web 3.0 时，脑海中是否会立刻浮现出区块链的画面？是的，我们习惯性地将 Web 3.0 与区块链联系在一起，但实际上，Web 3.0 可不仅仅是区块链的延伸。

近日，全球知名科技专家 Tony Sullivan 最新文章《Web 3.0 是真实存在的》呼唤了 Web 3.0 的来临，揭示了它并不是表面看上去那般简单。这篇令人惊艳的文章引发了广泛关注，让我们一同来探索 Web 3.0 的新面貌吧！

在过去的几十年里，我们见证了 Web 的快速发展与演变。从 Web 1.0 的静态页面、Web 2.0 的互动社交，到如今的 Web 3.0，互联网已经发生了天翻地覆的变革。Web 3.0 不再仅仅为人类所用，更多地将智能化与自主性引入其中。

那么，Web 3.0 究竟是什么？Sullivan 在文章中警示我们不要只局限于区块链的认知。他将 Web 3.0 定义为：通过分布式计算、人工智能和物联网等技术构建的智能化网络。它的出现，将推动整个互联网从中心化向去中心化发展。

对于普通用户而言，Web 3.0 提供了更加自主权威的网络环境。不再依赖互联网巨头的中心化掌控，Web 3.0 赋予了用户更大的数据掌握权，并以隐私与安全为基石，保护用户的数字身份。

而对于开发者而言，Web 3.0 则为他们带来了更广阔的创新空间。通过智能合约、去中心化应用（DApps）等技术，Web 3.0 打开了全新的商业模式，为开发者和企业家创造了更多可能性。

尽管区块链在 Web 3.0 中发挥了重要作用，但应当认识到，Web 3.0 不等同于区块链。Web 3.0 是一个更广义的概念，它包含了更多技术的集合，是一个全方位的演进。

在未来，我们将会看到越来越多的项目和应用基于 Web 3.0 的理念而展开。这是一个充满希望与无限可能的时代。让我们共同期待 Web 3.0 的正式来临，一同见证互联网的新变革！

无论是普通用户，还是开发者，Web 3.0 都带来了全新的机遇与挑战。沐浴在 Web 3.0 的光芒下，我们需要适应变革，不断学习与创新。因为，Web 3.0 的未来已经在向我们召唤，让我们握紧先机，迈入全新的网络时代！

详情参考

了解更多有趣的事情：https://blog.ds3783.com/
